THE JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY, HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 9, 1931

BETTER BUS SERVICE
In response to a request made
by President Ames, Mr. Tompkins, of the United Railways
and Electric Company of Baltimore, has arranged to have the
north-bound
Charles
Street
busses stop at the near side of
34th Street, after January 5,
thereby enabling any passengers
coming to the University to
cross Charles Street in greater
safety, being obliged therefore
to look out for only a sinee line
of traffic each way. The regular stop at 34th Street will be
continued.
During the first week the bus
chauffeurs will make this stop
every trip. After this week, they
will make it on:y on request.

HULLABALOO NOTICE
All seniors who have not already turned in their statistics
for the 1931 Hullabaloo should
do so at once. The office will
be open from 12 to 1 P. M.
every day next week for this
purpose, and the staff would appreciate the co-operation of the
class in this matter. No senior
will be written up for the Annual until he has complied with
this request.
If any of the forms placed
in the post office boxes for this
purpose have been lost, additional copies may be obtained
in the Hullabaloo office.

Californian English Prof
Addresses Tudor-Stuarts
Dr. Hardin Craig Speaks On Shakespeare's Revisions"

The Tudor and Stuart Literary
Club of the Johns Hopkins University, founded by Sir William and
Lady Osler, in memory of their son,
Edward Revere Osler, held its
ninth annual public lecture, in Levering Hall, Wednesday. The lecturer was Dr. Hardin Craig, Professor of English in the Leland
Stanford Junior University. His
subject was "Shakespeare's Revisions."

Clipping a second would
save 25,000 hours

H

A second saved here — an unnecessary
step cut out there — on such close attention to detail rests the success of modern
industry. Nowhere is this more strikingly
shown than in the telephone business.
In accounting work for instance, an
improved method that clips just one
second from the time required to handle
one toll ticket would have great results.

Applied throughout the System—handling an average of more than 90,000,000
toll tickets each month—it would effect
a monthly saving of 25,000 hours!
Such "little" things often are tremendously important in so vast an industry.
That is one reason why men find Bell
System work so fascinating.

JAY FISH OPEN SEASON
TOMORROW IN DELAWARE
Final Selection of Ten Men To
Represent Team Made at
Practice Wednesday
Tomorrow the Johns Hopkins
swimming team will travel to Newark, Delaware, to meet the University of Delaware in their initial
meet of the season.
Selections Made

At the practice held on Wednesday, final selection of the ten men
to represent the team was made. In
the dive, Reed and Temple are the
most likely prospects. Hoffman
and Gordon have been working a
backstroke. Captain Doeller, Frey,
Hanhart and Cruikshank are the
dash men, while Dorman, Stern and
Reisenstein are represented in the
breaststroke. Boyce and Cook are
the distance men.
Meets with several out-of-town
teams have been scheduled.

BETTER BUS SERVICE
In response to a request made
by President Ames, Mr. Tompkins, of the United Railways
and Electric Company of Baltimore, has arranged to have the
north-bound
Charles
Street
busses stop at the near side of
34th Street, after January 5,
thereby enabling any passengers
coming to the University to
cross Charles Street in greater
safety, being obliged therefore
to look out for only a sinee line
of traffic each way. The regular stop at 34th Street will be
continued.
During the first week the bus
chauffeurs will make this stop
every trip. After this week, they
will make it on:y on request.

HULLABALOO NOTICE
All seniors who have not already turned in their statistics
for the 1931 Hullabaloo should
do so at once. The office will
be open from 12 to 1 P. M.
every day next week for this
purpose, and the staff would appreciate the co-operation of the
class in this matter. No senior
will be written up for the Annual until he has complied with
this request.
If any of the forms placed
in the post office boxes for this
purpose have been lost, additional copies may be obtained
in the Hullabaloo office.

Californian English Prof
Addresses Tudor-Stuarts
Dr. Hardin Craig Speaks On Shakespeare's Revisions"

The Tudor and Stuart Literary
Club of the Johns Hopkins University, founded by Sir William and
Lady Osler, in memory of their son,
Edward Revere Osler, held its
ninth annual public lecture, in Levering Hall, Wednesday. The lecturer was Dr. Hardin Craig, Professor of English in the Leland
Stanford Junior University. His
subject was "Shakespeare's Revisions."

MODERN

WORLD

EMIOR1ALS

Clipping a second would
save 25,000 hours

H

A second saved here — an unnecessary
step cut out there — on such close attention to detail rests the success of modern
industry. Nowhere is this more strikingly
shown than in the telephone business.
In accounting work for instance, an
improved method that clips just one
second from the time required to handle
one toll ticket would have great results.

Applied throughout the System—handling an average of more than 90,000,000
toll tickets each month—it would effect
a monthly saving of 25,000 hours!
Such "little" things often are tremendously important in so vast an industry.
That is one reason why men find Bell
System work so fascinating.
The opportunity is there!

JAY FISH OPEN SEASON
TOMORROW IN DELAWARE
Final Selection of Ten Men To
Represent Team Made at
Practice Wednesday
Tomorrow the Johns Hopkins
swimming team will travel to Newark, Delaware, to meet the University of Delaware in their initial
meet of the season.
Selections Made

At the practice held on Wednesday, final selection of the ten men
to represent the team was made. In
the dive, Reed and Temple are the
most likely prospects. Hoffman
and Gordon have been working a
backstroke. Captain Doeller, Frey,
Hanhart and Cruikshank are the
dash men, while Dorman, Stern and
Reisenstein are represented in the
breaststroke. Boyce and Cook are
the distance men.
Meets with several out-of-town
teams have been scheduled.
